The Farm.
Second Crop In Peas.
After the hogs and stock have
had the run of the field as long as
possible, the land should be sowed
in some variety of the late matur
ing cow pea, such as the Unknown.
This pea sowed as late as the 10th
of July will harvest a magnificent
crop by the middle of October.
The value of the second crop,
planted in peas and without ferti
lizers, will fall but little short of
the value of the wheat crop. In
dependent of the high value of
the pea as a food for all kinds of
stock, we must not forget their
manurial value to the land, in
drawing and depositing in the soil
a large supply of free nitrogen
from the air. The stubble and
roots will supply humus to the soil
also, and build up the physical
condition of the land. If the wheat
field is laid off into rows three
feet apart and the peas drilled and
cultivated a heavier crop of peas
may be harvested, but it is cheap
er to broadcast, plow in and har
row, cutting the vines when the
pods are ripening, than otherwise.
As many acres as possible may be
cu’tivated in peas for gathering
and threshing out for seed to be
used next year for sale, but this
can be done better by dropping
and cultivating peas on the corn
rows. In the corn field, and fol
lowing wheat and oats, the cow
pea should be allowed all the space
that can possibly be devoted to its
growth. Cow peas should be a
system of rotation, be grown on
every acre-of land a farmer has,
once in every two or three years,
and annually if possible. Wherev
er it is grown there you have in
full operation a guano factory of
your own, actively engaged in
manufacturing and depositing in
the soil the highest priced plant
food, nitrogen, known to the chem
ist or to the farmer who has his
fertilizers to buy.
Two city farmers had their crops
of peas destroyed by the drought.
One came to condole with the oth
er: “Ah,” he said, “how unfor
tunate we have been. I have done
nothing ever since but fret. But,
bless me, you seem to have a fine,
healthy crop coming up just now.
What are these?”
“These? Why, these are what
I sowed immediately after our
loss.”
“What, coming up already?”
“Yes; while you were fretting I
was working.”
What, and don’t you fret when
you have a loss?”
“Yes, but I always put it off
until I have repaired the mis
chief.”
“Why, then, you’ve no need to
fret at all.”
“True, and that is the very rea
son. In truth, it is very pleasant
to have no longer reason to think
of misfortunes, and it is astonish
ing how many might be repaired
by a little alacrity and energy,
since,
“ ‘For every evil ’neath the sun
There is a remedy or none.
If there be one, at once go find it;
If there be none, then never mind
it.’ ”__
There is no better killing agent
for the insects of the poultry house
and cabbage field than the foliage
of the tobacco plant, and there is
not a farm or garden from the
New York State line south, but on
which enough could be grown for
the purpose, and not miss the
ground occupied. The leaves hung
in closets or packed with clothing
will prevent loss from insects, and
it is said roaches and other bugs
of the house will not stay where
the leaves are stored. It was an
old Roman maxim that the good
farmer never purchases that which
he can grow upon his land.
Mr. Youman, a farmer from
South Carolina, testified before the
Industrial Commission in Wash
ington, that he had no fault to
find with colored labor, and that
he preferred it infinitely to im
ported labor. “I employ 800 or
400 negroes,” he said, ‘‘and I find
them docile and willing to work.
I go away and leave my family
among them, feeling confident of
their safety and protection.”
The Threshing Machine.—
When the t h r e s h i n g machine
makes its appearance always have
plenty of help, so that the machine
can be every moment to feed its
fmll capacity. The enormous rev
, olution of the drum with its hea
vy iron spikes must be Jfully fed
with straw to prevent the break
ing and cracking of the grain. The
machine must have its rate of
speed carefully regulated to do
good work, and if there is not suf
ficent help to feed it as fast as is
required, the owner of the grain
is sure to suff r, and will blame
the machine, when it is not re
sponsible. If these conditions are
complied with and good work is
not done, you have a right to com
plain and should not hesitate to
do so. Watch the chaff box and
the travelling straw conductor,
examine the straw heads and see
I if all the grains are being proper
I ly knocked out. An old, worn
out, rickety threshing machine
will sometimes waste enough grain
in threshing a crop to pay the toll
usually charged.

IMPRISONMENT FOR DERT.
In recommending to the legislature of
South Carolina the abolition of imprison
ment lor debt, the Governor of that
State makes use of the following Forcible
observations:
“If the inability to pay a debt be a
crime, it should be, as other crimes are,
punished by the State, and the punish
meiii pc .portioned to the extent and mag
nitude of the offence. Hut if it be not
such an offence, as ought to draw down
upon it the severity of penal inhibition,
then to vest in any individual such a pow
er, 's 10 arm him with little les3 than
tie potic authority. The period which
was supposed to justily this cruel mea
sure has long since passed, and the be
nignant spirit of an enlightened age, re
gards with equal abhorrence, the injus
lic; of the mandate that now strips the
debtor of his liberty, and that which se
vered his body, and gave to each creditor
his proportioned share.—The State is in
jured, for it loses the efforts of a useful
citizen. The creditor is not benefited ;
for the imprisonment of his debtor will
not satisfy his claim. The debtor is the
double victim of bis misfortune and re
venge. If fraud is committed punish it
by severe enactment: if concealment be
perpetrated, expose the perpetrators to
infamous privations. But humanity and
justice, the tears of infancy and inno
cence, alike invoke prohibition of the
dangerous power now ceded to the cre
ditor." ——

MEMBRANCER.
TO give this work, though it can be nothing

made. Into it original dissertations on the
great doctrines and duties of Christianity, if
concise and argumentative, will be admitted.
But it will chiefly consist of useful and enter
taining extracts, religious, literary, historical
and miscellaneous, for the sake of those who
have not lime to read many hooks.
The following, and other topics, it will oc
casionally bring into view :—The origin and
progress of revealed religion; the most ma
terial religious controversies, which have been
agitated; answers to the principal objection* .
of Deists, Jews and others; the state of the
world and of the church under the Old Testa
ment, and since the commencement of the ,
Christian institution; Biblical difficulties, w ith J
a solution of them ; a sketch of the most use- 1
ful sciences; narratives of revivals of religion,
and of other occurrences of special impor
tance ; extracts from the reports of Bible and
other benevolent societies; notices of row
publications; biographical notices ; obituary
notices; and poetry. In short, it will contain
such matter as may render it interesting and
useful to the Christian public, and be conduct
ed on principles strictly evangelical.

THE DISSIPATED HUSBAND.
He cOtWesmot—l have watched the moon go do wn,
But yet he comes not—once it was not so.
He thinks not how these bitter tears do flow,
The while he holds his riot in that town.
Yet be will come, and chide, and I shall weep,
And he will wake my infant from its sleep,
To blend its feeble wailing with my tears.
O! how I love a mother's watch to keep,
Over those sleeping eyes, that smile which cheers
My heart, though sunk in sorrow, fixed and deep.
I had a husband once, who loved me—now
He ever wears a frown upon his brow,
And feeds his passion on a wanton’s lip,
As bees, from laurel flow’rs a poison sip;
But yet, I cannot hate—O! there were hours,
When 1 could hang for ever on his eye,
And Time, who stole with silent swiftness bvT
Strewed, as he hurried on, his path with flow’rs.
I loved him then—he loved we too—my heart
Still finds its fondness kindle, if he smile ;
The memory of our loves wil 1 ne’er depart;
And though he often stings me with a dart
VeiKimed and barbed, and waste upon the vile
Caresses which his babe and mine should share,
Though he should spurn me, I will calmly bear
His madness—and should sickness come, and lay
Its paralyzing hand upon him, then
I w ould, w ith kindness, all my wrongs repay,
Until the penitent should weep, and say,
How injured, and how faithful I had been. P.

THE EVENING HOUR.
The lonely, lovely, evening weeps;
The little dew-drops, soft descend;
On distant hills the moon-beam sleeps,
And nature’s charms with reason’s pleasures blend.
’Tis Love and Friendship’s blessed hour ;
’Tis Eden’s image lingering still,
When Fancy by her magic power,
Divests the cup of life of every ill.
Now health enjoys her blissful reign,
And toil and sorrow find repose,
The beams of hope burst fortii again,
And pledge an end to e’en my nameless woe?.
In mildest light, and softest shade,
Evening 1 Thou ever welcome guest,
In nature’s loveliest charms arrayed,
O soothe my sinking mind to sacred rest.
And be thou mine! since Heaven for me,
No genial bosom deigned to form ;
Thy solitude and shades shall be,
Like Mercy’s Angel in life’s ruthless storm.
I’ll love tire in thy simplest ’tire,
Constant, as thy own minstrel pays
The tribute of thy cricket lyre,
And sings the final hymn of passing day3.

Lite of Paul Jones.—lt is incumbent on us to
. notice, and we do it with great pleasure, the pub
lication of a volume elucidating the Life and
' Character of the celebrated John Paul Jones, by
i-a citizen of this place, although the work was
■ printed and published in New York. The great
: mass of documents brought together for this pur
pose, were partly discovered by accident, not
long since, and partly furnished to the Editor
from the offices of the General Government, and
by distinguished individuals. I hey consist of
letters, resolutions of Congress, correspondence
with many most eminent actors in the affairs of
our Revolutionary war, and of reports of J. P.
Jones himself, concerning the more interesting
scenes in which he was engaged. These are
connected with occasional narration to give them
intel legibility and consistency. The external
-appearance of the work is not entirely worthy of
the interesting matter it contains. As it is,
hew ever, it is a highly valuable addition to the
pub lie light which half a century has thrown
u^c n the actions and character of that inter
est in" generation which has just retired from
• stage, and can only live hereafter in the page
history. For although a few stragglers, of the
Jendid galaxy that conducted our country to
.^dependence and laid the foundation of its pre
> sent enviable condition, still survive ; it is not to
share the labors, but to receive, as companions
and representatives of the mighty dead, the ho
mage of the existing generation.
It was a singular happiness and honor for North
America, when the interests of the then British
colonies required a separation from the mother
country, that the unbending love of liberty was
associated with the love of order ; that the contest
was viewed by enlightened and liberal men eve
ry where, as a matter of much higher concern
ment than the mere local happiness of the inhabi
tants of these States. They considered it as a
struggle for the rights of man—as an experiment
that would try the problem whether absolute pow
er might not be put down, and good government
produced by agreement, by voluntary compact of
rhe People, the only rightful source of Power.
Hence eminent men of various nations, even some
claimed as native subjects of the very power we
had to contend with, volunteered as defenders of
American Liberty. Lafayette, Steuben, De
kalb, Pulaski, and Paul Jones, and many
others, may be mentioned among these, who had
more respect to principle, than national feeling ;
and who emphatically fought fur Liberty.
The event justified their enthusiasm, and, in
its consequences has shown, and will further
show, that the Battle of the World was fought in
the United States. It is the country of freemen
—the barrier between them and despotism ; to
this, as,his last earthly asylum, the patriot from
every part of the world turns his eyes.
It is good, therefore, to be brought more close
ly acquainted with those dauntless spirits that as
sisted in the great achievement for mankind. We
have hitherto known some of them only by a few
public actions. Of the celebrated subject of this
volume, the brilliant actions he performed have
been scarcely sufficient to redeem his character
from the obloquy and misapprehension with which
calumnious tradition loaded it. The present work
exposes the injustice, and furnishesus with a clear
insight into the very heart and feelings of Paul
Jones; and we hope it will be extensively diffus
ed and read.

ARRIVAL OF THE HORNET.
Norfolk, Aug. 5.
The United States’ sloop of war Hornet, E, P.
Kennedy, Esq. Commander, anchored at Old
Point Comfort last evening at 6 o’clock, in nine
days from Havana, having left that port on the
26th ult. To Captain Kennedy and Lieutenant
Cunningham, who came up from the ship last
night, we are indebted for the following intel
ligence :
The Hornet met going into Havana a French
fleet of IS men of war, 12 of them ships, four of
which of the line.
We regret to have to add to the list of valua
ble officers who have fallen victims to the inhos
pitable climate of the West Indies, Lieutenant
William Lawton, first of the Constellation, who
died on the 22d of July of the yellow fever. He
was a highly meritorious officer, and a gentleman
of great private worth. Lieutenants Henley and
Lawton were the only cases of fever that had oc
curred on board the Constellation, and both are
believed to have originated at Key West.
The t onstellation and John Adams were off
Havana, giving convoy. The Spark was cruiz
ing on the south side of Cuba. The Grampus,
Fox, and Terrier, were at Matanzas. We are
happy to learn, that the crews of all these vessels
both officers and men, were in excellent health,
not a case of fever (except the two above named)
having occurred on board of one of them.
The Hornet has been absent 13 months, and the
average number of sick daily reported for the
year ending the 30th July, have been about four
teen, making a total of 5110 patients attended
during the year ; of this number there h v ■ been
but four deaths, one of bilious remittent fever, one
of paralytic, one of disease produced by intoxica
tion, and the last (Doctor lan Brunt, the Sur
geon’s Mate,) of a lingering disease of the liver,
which had been brought on by a cruise in the
West Indies last year.
The greatest numberof sick reported at one time
was 64, all of which were cases of an epidemic
fever, that made its appe.arancs on board a few
days after the ship left St. Thomas, but by the
timely application of proper remedies, it disap
peared, without the loss of a single man. The
crew of the Hornet are now in a perfect state of
health, the sick report amounting only to four,
and these chronic case.s of debility only.

following sketch of his professional career :
“ Mr. IE was a native of James City, Va. and received

ing previously served.as a volunteer in the gun-boats
stationed at this place. In June following, he sailed for

ders to repair to New York, to join the ship Peacock,

having served in that arduous expedition for several
months, he returned to the U. S. in bad health, t'n his

ron, Commodore Warrington immediately selected Lt
Henley to as Captain of the fleet, in the exercise of the

Quantity of Blood in Animals.—Those who
have not considered the subject must be surpris
ed at the quantity of blood which passes through
the heart of any moderately sized animal in the
course of twenty-four hours. In man, the quan
tity of blood existing in the body at any given
moment, is probably from 30 to 40 pints. Of
-these, an ounce and a half, or about three table
spoonfuls, are sent out at every stroke ; which,
multiplied into 75, (the average rate of the pulse,)
give 1,125 ounces or seven pints in a minute,
i. e. 420 pints, or 25 1-2 gallons, in an hour, and
1,260 gallons, i. e. nearly 24 hogsheads, in a
day. Now, if we recollect that the whale is said
to send out from its heart at each stroke 15 gal
lons, the imagination is overwhelmed with the
aggregate of the quantity that must pass through
the heart of that animal in 24 hours. It is a ge
neral law that the pulse of the larger animals is
slower than that of the smaller; but even if we
put the pulse of the whale so low as 20 in tl)f
minute, the quantity circulated through the heart,
calculated at 15 gallons for each pulsation, will
be 432,000 gallons, equal to 8,000 hogsheads m
24 hours. The consideration of this amazing
quantity is, however, a su.ijectofmere empty won
der, if not accompanied with the reflection, that, in
orderto produce theaggregate amount,theheart is
kept in constant motion; and that, in fact, it is
incessantly beating, as it is termed, or throwing
out the blood into the arteries, from the first pe
riod of our existence to the moment of our death,
without any sensation of fatigue, or even without
consciousness, excepting under occasional corpo
real or mental agitation.

Government7.

accept.

country, nor aid, nor be trie means of aiding, the cause

party of native Americans, lor the cause ot the country,
and upon the principles as set loith in the above pream

Translation of a Letter from General La
fayftth to Gin. Bernard, of this city.
Parity Bth Sept. 1830.
Mr Dear General:
Abundance of news must have reached you
through the periodic,il papers. Nevertheless,
I think it will be, pleasing to you to receive
some written details. You will have receiv
ed some publications relating to our memora
,ble week. You will also have, read an account
of the Review by the King, in the Champ de
Mars, for the distribution of our tri-colored
flags to the National Guard. The ceremony
was as splendid as that of the Federation of
v 1790. We had five hundred thousand spec
tators; and every one was struck with the ce
lerity with which in less than three weeks we
'have organized nearly fifty thousand men of
National Guards—armed, equipped, and tiling
-off like veteran troops. The King handed
successively to the General Commander-in-
Chics the forty-eight ti i-colored flags, each
surmounted with a cock in lieu of the old im
perial eagle, and with this motto: “ Liberty-
Public Order—Days of 27th, 28th, 29th July.
1830.” The Commander-in-Chief took him
self the new oath, and had it administered to
the National Guard. The Colors were in
trusted to flag-bearers, selected from among
the mechanics who had distinguished them
selves in fighting in the barricades. The
National Guards are organizing throughout
France. We have already fourteen thousand
anew for the two arrondissements only of St.
Denis and Sceaux.
I send to you the order of the day which I
addressed to the National Guards of the king
dom. Next week, a law will be proposed for
the final organization of the French National
Guard. AH the citizens will compose the sta
tionary Guard ; the young men the moveable
National Guard. From seven to eight hun
dred thousand fighting men will thus form good
corps of reserve.
You know that some disturbances have ta
ken place in Belgium: they will end, I think,
by the separation of that country from Hol
land, under the same sovereign. We have
not interfered, except to signify that we shall
not suffer that any foreign army should exer
cise any right of interference, leaving the na
tions to manage their own affairs according to
their will, but not willing that other govern
ments shall interfere to oppress our neighbors.
1 send you the exact account of what has
taken place in the Chamber relative to South
America and Mexico. You will see that I
took care to mark the order of the recognitions
already made, and to give to our dear United
States the share which belongs to them.
Our republican throne has been recognized
‘immediately by the English Government, and
■will soon, I hope, be recognized also by the
other powers. You will readily suppose that
1 did not say that this was the best of Re
fhiblics. Ido not think so: and the Constitu
tion of the United States appears to me far
preferable. But I believe we have done for the
best in the present circumstances; and have
prepared, under a popular throne, all repub
lican institutions. There are not in France,
patriots more sincere and enlightened than the
King and his son. 1 knew them but little be
fore, but they have inspired me with the great
• ^st friendship and confidence; and this senti
ment is reciprocal.
This, my dear General', is the point at
which we have arrived. Ido not mention to
you some slight disturbances or errors among
the mechanics. There is not in all this any
ill intention, and reasoning alone has been
sufficient to persuade them. After all, most
*>f these slight disorders, of which our adver
saries have made so much, have been instiga
ted by disguised enemies; and there have been
no real troubles but at Nismes ; and the zeal
Of the neighboring. National Guards and that
of the Line, under the tri-colored flag, soon
depressed them.
Receive the new Assurances of my old and
constant friendship.
LAFAYETTE.
ORDER OF THE DAY.
Ta the National Guards of the Kingdom of
France, Sept. 1, 1830.
Th6‘ General Commanding in Chief the National Guards
of the Kingdom, called by the confidence of the People
to the head of the public force in the glorious days of our
late Revolution, has thought it his duty, notwithstanding
Siis refusal in 1790/ to accept, under the new state of
things, the important command conferred on him by the
■confidence of a patriot Monarch; himself placed by the
•wishes of his fellow citizens on the constitutional throne
•of the King of the French. But in consideration of the
importance and multiplicity of his duties;- the General
Commander in Chief must necessarily rely (of which he
ihas indeed the happy certainty) on the patriotism, upon
«the zeal, and he may be permitted to’ add, tiie personal
affection of his Brothers in arms throughout the vast ex-
Sent of our brave and free country of France.-
After forty years of memorable vicissitudes; the old
tri-colored flag of ’B9, the flag of the national sovereign
-iy, of liberty and of public order, has just beenglbrious-
Jy, generously and forever re-established—around this
standard has rallied with a spontaneous movement,' and'
will soon be legally organized, all France in armss
The French people, profiting by the lessons of ex
perience, by the progress of light, and civic intelligence,
and appreciating the glory and benefits of our political
storms; casting off all that deprived their first impulse of
their purity, feels much more the necessity for general1
and personal security, now that the happy division of
property and the advancement of industry, render it
more and more necessary. Filled with respect and good1
will for the rights of other nations, and their bosoms
glowing withardpur for all the rights, without distinction,
of individual, civil and religious liberty, they cannot but
maintain with- firmness, and if it be necessary, defend
with energy, their own rights of independence, liberty,
of legal order, the laws to which they have consented, and
the popular Throne which they have founded
It is the National Guards to whom these great duties
are particularly confided; and as no foreign influence
can prevail against the French nation, proud as she is of
her retrospections, of her strength, and of the great and
virtuous example she has just presented to the world,
holding in her hands the sacred arms of liberty, so nei
ther can any domestic intrigue, any of those temptations
to- disorder which the odious tactics of our adversaries
formerly rendered so oppressu'e^ffoW {ridmpli -over the
spirit of wisdoni; moderation, ana at the snyne time of
energy and persevering- patriotism which now characte
rize France as it is, and which was so’admirably evinced
by her brave men during the ihrec gredi days.
I'he General Commanding in Chief, ready at all times
to assist his fellow Soldiers with :dl the efforts -jof his de
votion and of his personal independence; communicates
to them this day some provisionary instructions, through
the medium of the Inspector General, whose3ong ex
perience has greatly aided his labors.
There will be no delay by the Government in the pre
sentation of a law for the final organization of the Na
tional Guards. It will have for its basis tire law of ’9l,
and especially the vital principle of election by the citi
zens ; but this is only an additional motive for forwarding
at present with all our zeal, the spontaneous movement
whichdocs honor and gives strength to Frahce, and which
presents her such as she ought to be to her Friends,
and in case of need to her Enemies.

.IMPORTANT FROM COLOMBIA.
Carthagena papers to September ,Bth, and
Bogota dales to August 28t.h, have been re
ceived at the office, of the New York Journal
of Commerce. Their contents arc highly im
portant. A revolution has taken place against
the government—a battle has been fought be
tween its partisans and its opposers—the latter
have been victorious and entered the capital.
The first document which presents itself to
our notice, is a “ Declaration of the Garrison
of the Capital of Magdalena,” pronounced in
Carthagcna on the 2d of August. It begins
thus :
“The Commandant General of the Departrn'ent (Ma
riano Montilla) having' received inforrnation of the De
claration of the Province of Socorro in favor cf the na
tion's remaining entire, and of the constitution recently
adopted, and declaring his Excellency the Liberator,
Generalissimo of the army; also, taking into considera
tion the critical circumstances of the capital (Bogota) in
consequence of the resolution taken by the Callao bat
talion and the neighboring population ; and considering
the imperious necessity which devolves upon this garri
son, of devising means without delay, for preserving the
integrity of (he Republic, and savingour population from
the horrors of anarchy; proceeds to convoke a Junta of
War, composed of all the officers in the place, in order to
hear their opinions, apd decide on the course of conduct
to be pursued in this important crisis.n
A meeting was accordingly held in the eve
ing of the same (lily, at which ail the officers
were present except , two, who were detained
by sickness, and one who was absent at his
country seat. Among those who attended
were Generals Carreiio, Uc'rds, O‘Leary,
Luque, and Blanco—seven Colonels, two Cap
tains of the Navy, ten First Commandants,
and various other .subordinate officers. The
following considerations were adopted by the
Junta :
1. That the communication with the capital is inter
rupted by besieging troops, and that the present condi
tion of the government is unknown.
, 2. That while the situation of the government is inti
mated by creditable letters from Honda, news has been
received from Venezuela, which in connexion with that
from Socorro, given us to understand distinctly the spirit
which prevals in the great body of the Republic.
3. That it is very probable the Declaration of Socorro
will be seconded by the other Provinces of the Depart
ment of Boyaca, and that the other Departments will
soon follow ; since it is well known by the public prints,
letters, &c., that a desire prevails for maintaining the in
tegrity of the Republic, and that His Excellency, the Li
berator, should take command of the army.
4. That as the army is the protector of the public li
befties, it seems to be in accordance with the will of the
people to declare for the same sentiments and support
thtem by their arms.
5. That the claims supported by the Callao battalion,
are not only theirs, but afeb the claims of the people in
the vicinity of the capital; and the individuals of mbst
respectability, honor and patriotism, within its precincts ;
and that these demands are justified by the conduct of
fife present Ministry.
6J. That this Ministry, at the head of a faction of de
magogues, and uncontrolled by reasons, has openly com
mitted a multitude of outrages upon the Constitution,
some of which have been stated in the public prints',
7. That the government being surrounded by this fac
tion; cannot possibly act: With freedom, or promote the
common felicity ; and that therefore it would be danger
ous,if not wfohg, to execute the orders which may ema
nate from the Ministry.
8. And lastly—That this Ministry ha# rendered itself
odious to the army by its unconstitutional acts, and be
cause most of its members’ receive the public execration
on account of their conduct, their connexion with the
conspiracy of 25th September, 1828, and’the protection
they have afforded and are still affording to the actors in
that scene, and the assassins of thb Grand Marshal of
Ayacucho [Gen. Sucre.}
I’he Junta then decided, almost triianimbus
ly, that under existing circumstances the
Commandant General ought not to' obey the
orders which he might receive from the Go
vernment at Bogota, and furthermore, that it
was his duty to render assistance, as far as
he was able without endangering the internal
security of the Department, to those Depart
ments which had declared, or might declare,
in favor of a change of Ministry, the Consti
tution, and the integrity of the Republic.
They also agreed to invite the Liberator to
place himself at the head of the army—al
though the Commandant General suggested
that such an invitation might give opportuni
ty to his enemies to accuse him of more ma
chinations, and to load him with new insults.
Gen. Briceno declared that he would obey no
other orders but those which emanated from
the Liberator, or from a Chief appointed’ by
the Liberator. A deputation was then chosen
to wait upon- his Excellency, ami inform him
of the wishes of the Junta. The Declaration
is signed by the Commandant General, and
by all the other officer^ present.
On the following day? Sept. 3, a similar
Declaration-was made by the civil officers and
principal citizens of Carthagcna. in the Sa
loon of the Palace, and is entitled the Pro
nunciamento of the capital of Magdalena.”
It is signed by the Prefect of the Department,
and numerous other citizens.

The Committee s Report on Farms in
Essex.
The farm of Mr. Jacob Perley, in
Newbury, contains about 180 acres, and
is well cultivated. The very fine ap
pearance of the orchards on his farm,
and the unusual size of the fruit, led to
the inquiry of the means by which this
was effected. Mr. Perley attributes it
principally to his mode of pfuning the
trees. Phis he does every year; and
takes off a much larger proportion of
the branches than is usually done. By
permitting the sun and air to have free
access to every branch of the tree, the
fruit will be richer, larger, fairer, and
more abundant This theory derives
support from the fact, that the fruit on
the southern side of a free is generally
much superior to that on the northern.
Another effect of annual pruning is to
produce annual bearing • and this Mr.
1 erley states to have been the case with
his trees, and those in the vicinity that
have been treated in a similar manner.
Several acres of cold, wet meadow
land on this farm have been reclaimed,
and rendered productive of the best up
land hay, by ditching and turning the
water from it, and then using the plough
and harrow, without any manure what
ever.
Mr. Perley has made some interest
i. g experiments upon manure; and stales
that he finds much advantage in convey
ing the wine of his cattle upon compost
heaps of earth and marsh mud. This is
a practice generally neglected by our
farmers. It is believed that, by proper
attention, nearly as much valuable ma
nuie can be made from the urine as
from the dung of the cattle.
The firm of Capt. Paul Kent, situate
on Kent’s Island, (so called) in Newbu
ry, contains about 250 acres. Capt.
Kent lias paid considerable attention to
the cultivation of root crops, and is mak
ing some interesting experiments to as
certain their comparative value. Of
those that he has tried he prefers the
common blood beet and the mangel
wurtzel, [scarcity beet] but which of
the two be has not fully determined.
On the comparative value of root crops
and Indian corn as food for swine, Capt.
Kent lias made some experiments, and
believes that corn is much to be prefer
red in fattening swine.
The lands of Mr. Tristram and Hen
ry Mittle, ofAewbury, were visited by
the Committee with much satisfaction.
Their field of mangel wurtzel is the fin
est we have ever seen; and we doubt
not that the produce will be at least one
thousand bushels to tbe acre—equal in
value to ten tons of the best of En
glish hay.—Their experiments on In
dian corn haye heretofore been very
successful, as the premiums of this and
the State Society will abundantly testi
fy. In Ihe present year, we are of the
opinion that their field is planted quite
too thick—that it contains twice as ma
ny stalks as will be found profitable. It
is planted in rows, and has several stalks
to every square foot of land. It seems
to be their opinion that the best mode of
planting corn is in hills, from three to
four feet apart, and with from four to
six stalks in a hill. Care should be tak
en in the selection of the seed ;—this
should be done in the field, from the fair
est and earliest stalks;—and where two
well ripened earsare found on one stalk,
they are always to be preferred as being
more productive. It is important that
the ears earliest ripe be selected,
for their produce will ripen earlier in
the succeeding year ; and hence yield a
safeguard against early frosts, the most
dangerous enemy to this most valuable
of crops. Without good seed it is vain
to expect large products; and the little
attention necessary to produce the best
seed will be abundantly rewarded in the
quality and quantify of the harvest.
Their field of English turnips exceeded
any thing of the kind witnessed else
where. We were informed that they
hid raised of this crop more than six
hundred bushels to the acre, after a crop
of grass had been taken from the land,
in this way may the farmer easily reme
dy the evil consequences of a short crop
of hay ;—a few acres well cultivated
with turnips will fully supply all the de
ficiencies that ordinarily occur.—Their
turnij* were planted in rows about two
feet apart, and so thinned that the
plants were not permitted to grow
within ten or twelve inches of each oth
er. They hoe them several times, and
take care that the ground is kept loose
about them, and free from weeds.
The farm of Mr. William Thurlow,
situate in W. Newbury, contains about
150 acres. It is distinguished for hav
ing the largest and most productive ap
ple orchard in the county. There are
upon it 2500 grafted trees in a beating
condition. Jn some seasons they have
yielded more than 1000 barrels of sound
and fair winter apples, worth at least
1200 dollars. Mr. Thurlow suffers
sheep only to teed in his orchard grounds.
Ihe limbs of his trees being low, he
does not permit cattle of any descrip
tion to go among them. He never
ploughs the land about the trees, or ap
plies any manure to them. He prunes
them more or less annually. Their
flourishing condition must be attributed
to the peculiar adaption of the soil to
their growlh, and its superior natural
strength and fertility. Most of Nr.
1 hurlow’s trees produce the common
Roxbury russet apple. This is a valu
able fruit, and pretty sure to bear ; lut
lately other species have come into use
much more valuable. Our farmers gen
erally appear not sufficiently attentive,
in grafting their trees, to obtain the best
kinds ci fruit. Regard, also, should be
had to the character of the tree fram
which the scions are takenthat it be
thrifty, productive, and constant in bear
ing; and that it be of a kind of fruit
that is not on the decline, or, in the fir
mer’s phrase, nearly run out. Natural
fruits, of trees growing from the seeds,
are occasionally found of excellent qual
ities, either for cider or eating. These
should be preferred in grafting.

misfortune—“Ah!” .cried he, “ how in
fortnnate we have been, neighbour! Do
y,ou know 1 have done nothing but f-et
ever since. But bless me ! you seenito
have a fine healthy crop coming npjjst
now.—Wba» are these ?” “ These ? (said

diately sowed after my loss.” “ What,

“ Yes, you was fretting I was

LORD BYRON.
The Reviewer of Shelley’s posthumous Poems,
in the last number of tho Edinburgh Re
view, thus alludes to the death of Lord By
ron :
“To this band of immortals* a third
has since been added!—a mightier ge
nius, a haughtier spirit, whose stubborn
impatience and Achilles-like pride on
ly death could quell. Greece, Italy,
the world, have lost their poet-hero;
and his death has spread a wider gloom,
and been recorded with a deeper awe,
than has waited on the obsequies of any
of the many great who have died in
our remembrance. Even detraction has
been silent at his tomb ; and the more
generous of his enemies have fallen into
Ihe rank of his mourners. But he set
like the sun in his glory; and his orb
was greatest and brightest at the last;
for his memory is now consecrated no
less by freedom than genius. He prob
ably fell a mariyr to his zeal against ty
rants. He attached himself to the cause
of Greece, and dying clung to it with a
convulsive grasp, and had thus gained
a niche in her history; for whatever
she claims as hers, is immortal even in
decay, as the marble sculptures on the
columns of her fallen temples.”

our of their skin, according to the col
our of the substance on which they are
placed, and of subsisting upon air. This
belief has arisen from the extraordinary
s;ze of their lungs, which they are capa
ble of distending with air to such an e
normous extent, as to fill nearly their
whole body, and render their skin some
what transparent.—Hence they were
said to feed upon air. In this state of
distention and semi-transparency, the
Akin becomes easily affected by every
change in the circulation ; and conse
quently a change of colour is produced
by the varying wants and passions of the
animal, which influence both the quanti
ty of respiration and the tint of the
blood.

The Death. Watch.—Among the popu
lar superstitions which the illumination
of modern times has been able to obliter
ate, the dread of the Death Watch may
be considered as one of the most pre
dominant, and still conlinues to disturb
the habitations of rural tranquillity with
absurd apprehensions. It is chiefly in
the advanced state of Spring that this
little animal commences its rounds,
winch is no other than the call or signal
by which the male and female are led to
each other, and which may be consider
ed as analogous to the call of birds ;
though not owing to the insect, hut te
its beating on any hard substance with
the shield or fore part of its head. The
prevailing number of distinct strokes
which it beats is from 7 to 9, or 11, which
very circumstance may still add in some
degree to the ominous character which
it bears among the vulgar. These
sounds or beats are given in pretty quick
succession, are repeated at uncertain in
tervals, and in old houses, where the
insects are numerous, & may be heard at
almost every hour of the day—espec
ially if the weather be warm.’ The in
sect is of colour so nearly resembling
that of decayed wood, that it may for a
considerable time elude the search of
the inquirer. It is about a quarter of
an inch in length, and is moderately
thick in proportion, and the wing shells
are marked with numerous irregular
variegations, of a lighter or grayer col
our than the ground colour.

“ The morning following (he battle

The way to confess.—A man confessing
his sins to a priest, among other sins of
which he accused himself, said, that a
few hours before, he had beat bis wife.
The father confessor asked him the rea
son why? He answered that it was be
cause he had so short a memory, be
could never remember the sins he had
committed, but whenever he beat his
wife, she reproached him with all the ill
he had ever done in his life ; by which
he was able to make a general confes
sion with very little trouble, and for ten
pence more obtain a perfect absolution.

To minds of an ordinary cast, patient
indolence under settled prospects come?
as a matter of course ; it requires no
effort, and is endured without suffering.

nature, what penance so hard to be
borne as that which imposes stillness

is with them to be nothing—worse than
nothing. Philosophers have spoken,

thing in nature indicates, that earthly fe
licity can only dwell in (he pursuit of
simple quiet pleasures. But what are
these lessons to those souls of fire,
which, whilst the world goes round,
will ever be found therein ?

getting right, nothing can be more

Vr. Editor: In this District, where the
soil is not very rich, the planter must turn
His attention to ma kin;- iHii,lle
the soil. Already has the climate been
changed, by the inconsiderate custom of
clearing lands every year; for it has
become- sicklier, colder, end therefore
less congenial to the culture of cotton. The
soil is light and easily, worked. And why
should we not avail ourselves of these ad
vantages? .Not one planter or farmer in ten,
thinks of manuring at all. While one will
be deriving fine .crops from manuring, his
next-door neighbor will not deign to inquire
into the cause. Even those who turn their
attention to manures do not understand the
plainest chemical elements by which they
are to "be regulated in its production Be
cause it may be. beneficial to manure with
cotton seed On top, a planter will use cow
pen and stable manure in the same way,
as if the sun would not extract much of the
strength of the manure, before it could be
covered with the plough. Cotton seed can
be used on top; because, Tiefore it ferments,
and before the sun can extract its alimentary
properties, it is covered in the working of
corn. I only mention this to show, that our
planters, by not thinking for themselves, are
frequently inconsistent. There is my neigh
bor, Squire Suooks, who, the .moment his
manure arrives in the field, covers it with
dirt, and yet he, manures his corn with it,
on lop.
The best planters up here adopt this plan
of making ma nure.
I. lne stables are lined with oak leaves,
rotten wood, (oak best) pine trash, heaped
in the woods for at least six months before
used, all kinds of trash, gum pond mud, and
lomeumes Cray, wen broken up. i nis is
taken out of the stables every two months, if
possible, during a rain, heaped and covered
with clay or sand; if not during a rain, pour
upon the heap, before covering it, a suffi
cient-quantify of water to assist in fermenta
tion. Even while the mass is in the stable,
a little water, occasionally sprinkled, with
the use of the grubbing-hoe at least once a
week, will' have a good effect. By grubbing
with the hoe, the animal is effectually com
bined with the vegetable manure, and lumps
of clay or rotten wood, are pulverized
2. The poultry houses and yards are
cleaned once a month, and the yield there
fVom, thrown into the stable.
3. All the Pride pf India berries are raked,
and thrown into the stable.
4. There is a. pen, six feet square, and
aix feet deep," below the surface, of the earth,
filled with leaves, and covered, into which
the cook and washer throw their slops and
suds. This is emptied at the proper time,
heaped, and covered with trash, &,c.
5. Hog-pens" are ' made, six feet square,
and six feet below the surface of the earth,
filled with leaves, and protected from the
rain. The floor is made of rails, through
the intervals of which, the animal matter
of the hogs is dropped. On the floor is a
Covering of pine-trash, for beds, which the
sharp feet of the hogs will, in a short time,
cut into fine pieces. The hogs are either
penned here the whole year, or sleep in them
every -night, or, at all events, are put up at
'" least one month" to fatten', for bacon. , Ma
nure thus made is equal to "cotton-seed."
6. Each negro is allowed Jo keep one or
two hogs, on condition that they are penned,
as above stated." Hogs fatten pest on wood
en floors; and though : raw cotton-seed will
kill them, they fatten on it when boiled with
the offals of the garden ana fields. xney
do not like cold or rain, and, : in the end, it
would be decidedly cheaper to pen them all
the year, except when they are allowed to
run the pea, potato, and slip fields. In the
way I haVe described, they will make more
manure than the cotton seed "they eat. Be
sides, there is nothing safer than to have our
hogs always in sight. - B'
7. Cattle pens. The manure made in
the3e pens is. always indifferent, unless they
be covered. In this particular, our planters
up here, labor under a great mistake. Their
plan is this: Leaves and trash, thrown in
to a pen, are trampled on by cattle, exposed
to the weather, and, by the time the mass is
heaped for fermentation, the best part of its
manuring qualities has evaporated. , On the
other hand, when in stalls, the leaves are not
only trampled, but they absorb the animal
matter, and retain it until the manure is used1.
A cow, when stalled, will make four times
the manure of a horse, in a year. Its dung
is more susceptible of -combination with ve
getable matter; and, for the same reason, it
is rendered quickly inert, by the action of
the sun. I have tried the difference between
dried and fresh cow-dung, under corn. The
former had no effect; while Jhe latter forced
the corn very much. Cow pens should be
covered, and the cattle turned in every night.
However, after all, the most profitable plan
is to stable feed milch cows and oxen; in this
district, where we are compelled to feed cat
tle, one half of the year, they should be fed
with boiled cotton-seed. That cotton-seed,
for corn, is superior to any manure we use,
cannot W doubted; but, at the same time;
when the improvement of cattle is consider
ed, the increase of their milk and butter, their
protection from theives, and the undoubted
fact, that they can be made to produce, in
six months, four times more efficient manure
than the cotton seed they consume, I do not
hesitate to contend, that, the better policy
would be, to stable-feed them on boiled cot
ton seed, for six months in the year, or during
the winter season. Any cow can be taught
to eat cotton seed, by adding a little salt.
A stall filled with leaves ctsn be emptied
every two months. The cow drops more
than the horse, and it tramples more effectu
ally it3 hoofs being sharp and wide. Ano
ther consideration is this: with cow pen ma
nure thus mnde, land is enriched ever' time
it is planted, and in this respect it is more
valuable than cotton seed. In short, to use
cow pen manure, raked from an uncovered
pen, except lor the undecomposed vegetable
matter, in it, is always a useless task. In
nine cases out of ten, it will fire the corn,
even in a moderately wet senson. On the
contrary, stable manure never will; nor does
any well fermented manure ever fire the
plant. A gentleman in my parts has advan
ced one step towards this improvement.
When the mass, in his unroofed pen, has
been sulhciently trampled, h i -,;u.
clay, and on this places another layer of
leaves, ana so on, alternating', unui ne nas
made the ouantitv of manure he reouires.
But even this gentleman is engaged in build
ing a stable for his cows. He says, by experi
ment, 3 bushels of cotton seed per week, wiU
fatten a cow, and 2 1-2 bushels, with shuck?,
are enough. 50 bushels of seed, from two
bale3 of short cotton, would enable him to
stall-feed his cattle during the winter the
season when manure is made, and when cat
tle suffer most for range. So that, after de
ducting seed for planting from everv 50
bushels of cotton seed, he caculates to stall
feed one cow. He further says, that he will
not be able to stall-feed all his eattle, but
that all those not supnlied wilL.be turned
nightly into an open pen, filled with leaves,
with which he will replenish the stalls when
ever they may be emptied. D.

Farmers, who were neighbors, had their crops
of early peas killed bv die frost. One of them
came to condole with the other on their mis-
Jbitune. "Ah!" cried he, 'how unfortunate
we have been neighbor! you seem to have
done nothing. But bless me! you seem to
have a fine heallhy crop coming up just now:
what are these?" "1 hese," said the other;
"why, these are what I sowed immediately af
ter my loss." "What coming up already?"
cried the fietter. "Yes; while you were fret
ting I was working." "What and don't you
fret when you have a loss?" "Yes, but I al
ways put it ofTuntil I have repaired the mis
chief." "Lord! why then you've no need to
fret at all." "True," replied the industrious
gardtier, "and that's the very reason; in truth
it is very pleasant to have no longer reason to
think of misfortunes; and it is astonishing how
many might be repaired by a little alacrity and
energy." '. .

FROM FLORIDA.
The subjoined article would seem to contra
dict the statement copied in our last from a
New Orleans paper of the 6th instant. The
New Orleans statement, however, as it appears
to have been made upon the authority of Gen.
Macomb himself, (who must best know what has
passed between him and the Indians,) must be
yet relied upon until it shall appear, from the
same authority, that the facts of the case were
misunderstood there.
FROM.THE TALLAHASSEE FLORIDIAN, MAY 4.
“ A short time since, the hostile Indians under Nehe-
Stoco Matta, principal chief of the Tallahassees, with one
hundred warriors, went into Tampa and carried off all the
Indian prisoners at that post. They likewise returned the
night following, crossed the river, and reconnoitred the
post and barracks. They refused to come in to treat with
the whites, and left word with a white man whom they
held prisoner during one night, that if General Macomb
wished to treat with them he must come to their camp.”
The following letter has been furnished to
the editors of the Philadelphia Pennsylvanian :
EXECUTION OF THE PIRATE MARS AUD,
AT BORDEAUX.
Captain Marsaud, who murdered the Captain and part
of the crew, and took command of the French ship Alex
andre, (which vessel was seized at Newport, Rhode Island,
some time since, and sent under the command of an officer
from on boird a French man-of-war to Bordeaux,! has
been tried, found guilty, an! executed at Bordeaux for the
above crime. A young man, his second officer, has also
been tried and found guilty, but, on account of his age,
has been recommended to mercy. The execution of Mar
saud took place three hours after the passing of his sen
tence. Before his death he made a full confession of all
his crimes. He said that seven men were ‘l own over
board by his order, and that the mate of t> -ship implo
ringly begged of him only one half-hour’s ..me in order
that he might write to, and take a last farewell of, his mo
ther, and offered him (Marsaud) the sum of 30,000 francs
for said half hour, but that he unmercifully denied it to
him.
Il is very much wondered at, in Bordeaux, why it was
that the French authorities in the United States experi
enced so much difficulty from the American magistrates in
having such a monster given up. It is also stated that
four of the piratical crew who had a hand in the above
mutiny and murders are still in the United States, and
that all the entreaties of the commander of the French
man-of-war Bergere could not induce the Americans to
give them up.
The United States schooner Wave, under the command
of Lieutenant M’Laughlin, has rendered eminent service
to our commerce on the Capes of Florida. This vessel
has saved the lives of twenty men of shipwrecked crews,
that would have otherwise fallen a prey to the marauding
savages; also, a large amount of wrecked property has
been rescued, and the haunts of men who have furnished
munitions to the Indians have been broken up.
A Breach in the Canal.—A breach was made in the
Delaware and Chesapeake Canal on Saturday last, at a
portion of the works about four miles from Delaware city.
The injury, it is said, is so great, that it cannot be repaired
in a shorter time than two months. Forty or fifty sail of
vessels, laden with lumber and other articles from that city
and Port Deposite, are now confined in the canal, or have
been obliged to return up the bay or put to sea.
Judge King, Chief Judge of the Court of Common Pleas
in Philadelphia, a few days since, during the trial of an
insane negro for the. murder of a watchman, in his remarks
to the jury, commented on the enlightened policy of pro
viding for insane paupers at the public charge; and observ
ed, in highly complimentary terms, that Maryland had
acquired for herself great honor by the recent liberal appro
priation for that object.
* Pensacola, May 4, 1839.
The United States sloop of war Vandalia, Capt. Levy,
arrived here on Tuesday evening last in 8 days from La
guma Terminoz, where the Captain was detained some
days adjusting the difficulty between the late Consul and
the Mexican authorities. On the 13th the Vandalia sail
ed from Vera Cruz, leaving the Ontario at anchor. The
French and English squadrons were about leaving, and
the city becoming settled and quiet. The loss by the fire
was estimated at $500,000. The flag ship, with the Eriet
Levant, and Warrent was daily expected.
A bunch of Asparagus from the garden of William H.
Richardson, near Richmond, (Va.) was weighed by Mr,
Diddep, Clerk of the Market, on Saturday morning, the
11th inst. It contained six stalks, or spears, and weighed
one pound thirteen ounces !—Whig.
Bones of a Mastodon.—Our readers will recollect of
reading some time last summer of the discovery of the
bones of a gigantic animal in Crawford county, Ohio.
These bones are now in Pittsburgh, Pa. The bones of
the head, including a number of grinders, are in a remark
able state of preservation; and some faint idea of what the
living animal was, may be formed, when we state that the
skull and upper jaw are 3 feet 3 inches in length, and weigh
160 lbs. the lower jaw 77 lbs.—the whole head 237 lbs. of
dry bones! There are many other bones—legs, ribs, ver
tebrae, &c. all in a good state of preservation.—Pittsburg
Advocate.
FROM THE SALISBURY WATCHMAN.
Excursions.—ls we were to chronicle all the interesting
passages that are reported to us as occurring to the plea
sure parties that go abroad from this place, we should pre
sent a budget of fun and adventures rare. In one instance,
on a visit to the Narrows of the Yadkin, a fair one got
fastened in the rocks, so that one of her beaus had to knock
her out of her difficulty : another lost her stockings in an
adventure somewhat similar, and had to walk about five
miles without them. On another occasion, a gentleman
who had the reputation of a gallant squire, undertook the
navigation of a canoe; but he found his craft somewhat
unmanageable, and while going through a rapid stream,
at the rate of ten knots, he undertook to make a short halt
by putting down the pole immediately below it. As might
be expected, he took an aerial flight of some fifteen feet, and
was landed in the water, as Paddy would tell you. He
was taken up considerably down the river, and immediate
ly proposed 11 to go home.” Some of the ladies showing
an inclination to laugh at his misfortunes after the danger
was discovered to be over, our buck replied, with some
show of impatience, “ Well, fishing is a pleasant business,
but to be fished for aint quite to my liking.”
Ups and Downs.—We observe a striking instance of
the uncertain tenure of earthly goods, in a case lately re
ported in the London papers. It was a prosecution for per
jury, in the course of which it was given in evidence, that
the prosecutrix, Lady Parker, becoming security for her
sister, Lady Lake, for the sum of £19,000, in consequence
of legal proceedings for its recovery, became an inmate of
the King’s Bench Prison, where she officiated as cook to
the more wealthy portion of the prisoners.—American.
True Philosophy—The Farmers.—Two farmers, who
were neighbors, had their crops of early pease killed by the
frost. One of them came to condole with the other on their
misfortune. “Ah ! ’ cried he, “ how unfortunate we have been,
neighbor ! I have done nothing but fret ever since. But, bless
me ! you seem to have a fine healthy crop coming up just now :
what are these?” “ These,’’ said the other; “ why, these are
what I sowed immediately after my loss.” “ What, coming up
already ?” cried the fretier. “ Yes ; while you were fretting I
was working.” “ What! and dont you fret when you have a
loss ? ’ “ Yes, but I always put it off until I have repaired the
mischief.” Lord ! why then you’ve no need to fret at all.”
“True,” replied the industrious gardener, “ and that’s the very
reason ; in truth, it is very pleasant to have no longer re&son to
think of misfortunes; and it is astonishing how many might be
repaired by a little alacrity and energy.”

every citizen of the old States. Mr. Clay has,

THE STATES AND THE CANADAS.
The Canadian and American Frontiers.—
The late report of Lord Durham on the affairs
of Canada thus contrasts the appearance of the
American and Canadian shores :
“On the American side, all is activity and bustle. The
forest has been widely cleared ; every year numerous settle
ments are formed, and thousands of farms are created out
of the waste; the country is intersected by common roads ;
canals and railroads are finished, or in the course of forma
tion ; the ways of communication and transport are crowd
ed with people and enlivened by numerous carriages and
large steamboats. The observer is surprised at the num
ber of vessels they contain ; while bridges, artificial land
ing places, and commodious wharves are formed in all di
rections as soon as required.
“Good houses, warehouses, mills, inns, villages, towns,
and even great cities, are almost seen to spring up out of
the desert. Every village has its school house and place
of public worship. Every town has many of both, with its
township buildings, its book stores, and probably one or
two banks and newspapers; and the cities with their fine
churches, their great hotels, their exchanges, court-houses,
and municipal halls of stone or marble, so new and fresh as
to mark the recent existence of the forest where they now
stand, would be admired in any part of the old world. On
the British side of the line, with the exception of a few fa
vored spots, where some approach to American prosperity
is apparent, all seems waste and desolate. There is but
one railroad in all British America, and that running be
tween the St. Lawrence and Lake Champlain is only 15
miles long. The ancient city of Montreal, which is natu
rally the commercial capital of the Canadas, will not bear
the least comparison in any respect with Buffalo, which is
a creation of yesterday.
“ But it is not in the difference between the larger towns
on the two sides that we shall find the best evidence of our
own inferiority. That painful but undeniable truth is most
manifest in the country districts through which the line of
national separation passes for 1,000 miles. There, on the
side of both the Canadas, and also of New Brunswick and
Nova Scotia, a widely scattered population, poor, and appa
rently unenterprising, though hardy and industrious, sepa
rated from each other by tracts of intervening forests, with
out towns or markets, almost without roads, living in mean
houses, drawing little more than a rude subsistence from
ill cultivated land, and seemingly incapable of improving
their condition, present the most instructive contrast to
their enterprising and thriving neighbors on the Ameri
can side.”
The 11 Winter Studies and Summer Rambles”
of Mrs. Jamison has a passage to the same
effect :
“ I hardly know how to convey to you an idea of the
difference between the two shores; it will appear to you as
incredible as it is to me incomprehensible. Our shore is
said to be the most fertile, and has been the longest set
tled ; but to float between them, (as I did to day in a little
canoe made of a hollow tree, and paddled by a half-breed
imp of a boy,) to behold on one side a city with its towers
and spires and animated population, with villas and hand
some houses stretching along the shore, and 100 vessels or
more, gigantic steamers, bridges, schooners, crowding the
port, loading and unloading; all the bustle, in short, of
prosperity and commerce; and, on the other side, a little
straggling hamlet, one schooner, one little wretched steam
boat, some windmills, a catholic chapel or two, a supine
ignorant peasantry, all the symptoms of apathy, indolence,
mistrust, hopelessness! Can anyone help wondering at
the difference, and ask whence it arises? There must be
a cause for it surely—but what is it ? Does it lie in past or
in present—in natural or accidental circumstances? In
the institutions of the Government or the character of the
People? Is it remediable? is it a necessity? is it a mys
tery? What and whence is it ? Can you tell? or can you
send some of our colonial officials across the Atlantic, to
behold and solve the difficulty ?”
Asphaltum Pavements.—One of the warm days of the
week before last the admirable asphaltum pavement in Bour
bon street was so affected by the heat of the weather as to
be rendered all but impassable. Horses left the imprints of
their hoofs after them in the melted substance, and the
marks of wheel carriages are still plainly discernible. We
begin to have some serious apprehensions of its running
away in the dog days, and would advise, as a timely pre
ventive, the laying of a thicker coat of bitumen over the
bricks, or the boiling of it down to a stiffer consistency. 4

Removal or The City Post Office.—Having, a short
time ago, stated, on what we then considered to be good
authority, that the City Post Office was not intended to be
removed from its present location, at the corner of Four
and-a-half street and Louisiana avenue, it surprised us to
learn, a few days ago, from good authority, that it had been
finally determined to give up the present location, and rea
move the City Post Office to the cornet Of Twelfth street.
On the north side of Pennsylvania avenue. By reference
to the proceedings of the Washington Corporation, pub
lished in this day’s paper, it will be seen that the contem
plated removal of the City Post Office has been brought
under discussion in the two Boards, and a resolution of
Mr. Watterston passed by a very large majority in the
Board of Aidermen and Board of Common Council, autho
rizing the Mayor to wait upon the President of the United
States and respectfully to request that the City Post Office
may not be removed from its present location until the
meeting of Congress.
Since writing the above, we learn that Mr. Fuller has
entered into a contract with the Postmaster General for
the renting of the building at the corner of Twelfth street,
for the new City Post Office, and that the workmen com
menced their operations yesterday morning. Moreover, it
is now stated, by a person well advised on the subject, that
it is not contemplated to locate the City Post Office in the
new building on Seventh street, but permanently at the
corner of Twelfth street and Pennsylvania avenue. It
needs not the gift of prophecy to foretell that Congress will
let the Postmaster General know whose is the controlling
authority in reference to this matter, his’or theirs. Weare
not sure, indeed, that, without the intervention of Congress,
those whose rights of property are in the way of being in
jured by the rumored permanent removal of the City Post
Office from its old site, would not have a remedy against
the Postmaster General, under the act of Congress of
March 7, 1812, (directing where the Post Office shall be
kept,) by a process at law.
Coroner’s Inquest.—On Saturday, the Hth instant,
an inquest was held in the city of Washington, before
Thomas Woodward, Esq., Coroner of the county, upon
view of the body of Cyrus Jackson, a slave, nearly sixty
years of age, the property of James Maher, of the Globe
tavern, who had come to his death by a wound inflicted on
his head on the evening of the 10th instant, by which his
skull was fractured, and of which wound he died about
the hour of five on the morning of the 11th instant.
After a careful and patient investigation, occupying full
four hours, the following verdict of the jury was delivered
by George Sweeny, Esq. foreman: “ That the deceased
came to his death by a deep wound on his head ; but how
the said wound was caused or inflicted, the testimony is
not sufficient to enable the jury to form a satisfactory
judgment.”

Messrs. Editors : Your correspondent, “ B,” seems not
to have read the article Bn Graveyards, to which he re
plies, with much attention. I spoke of the other grave
yards of the city as being comparatively “ but little used;”
and admitted that the description of their condition by
“G” “ was correct.” I attributed their neglected condi
tion to that fact, and certainly meant nothing offensive
when I spoke of the "humble graves” in these burial
grounds. There are many such graves in the burial
ground which I have attempted to describe in the commu
nication referred to, and your correspondent must, I think,
admit that the graves of all who have not been distin
guished in life may, without giving offence, be properly
termed humble. I have myself, like the friend he alludes
to, wept over the humble graves of two beloved children
snatched from me in early life, and whose remains moulder
into dust in the fine burial-ground of which I have spoken,
and have felt the truth of the beautiful lines of Males
herbes:
“Elle etoit de ce monde, ou les plus belles choses
Ont le pire destin;
Et Rose elle a vegue comme vivent les roses,
L'espace d'un matin.”
But he, like myself, may derive consolation from the
thought that, in the language of Klopstock, they are
“Seed sown by God, to ripen for the harvest.”
I regret to say that the city authorities, which your cor
respondent “ B” undertakes to censure for the want of an
“ efficient police” for these graveyards, have unfortunately
not the means to provide an efficient police for those parts
of the city which are vastly more populous with the liv
ing, and where such a police would be much more useful.
They have done, perhaps, all that they deem it necessary
to do, by appointing commissioners and sextons for the
public or Corporation burial-grounds of the city, in one of
which (the eastern) no interments, I believe, are now made,
or have been made for several years. It was originally
much used, but, in consequence of the superior locality
and security of the Congressional burial-ground, it has
been almost entirely abandoned, and, I regret to say, is
now overrun with brambles and underwood—very much,
I confess, to the discredit of the Corporation.
Your correspondent seems to have a strange conception
of the effect of newspaper comments upon local subjects,
and thinks that they leave no “ impression upon the minds
of any but such as are individually concerned in the mat
ter” commented on. This is a mistaken notion. Every
one knows the reputation our city once had for unhealthi
ness, in consequence of the false and exaggerated state
ments published concerning it. Were a citizen to under
take to charge the metropolis, in one of the public prints
here, with being the most corrupt and profligate city in the
Union, your correspondent would soon find that the slan
der was not confined to Washington, but would be seized
upon by almost every press in the United States, and cir
culated from one extremity of the Country to the other.
And I do not know that such language as the following,
used by your correspondent, namely, "all speak a want of
police and depravity of feeling that I have never seen ex
hibited in such places in any other part of the Union,” may
not be made a handle of by persons at a distance, to dishonor
the character of our city. I believe that the citizens of
Washington are not peculiar for depravity of feeling, or
the neglect of their dead. The dead are not more respected
and honored elsewhere. The living are too apt to neglect
those who have passed away from this world; but the
people of Washington cannot with justice be charged
with being more indifferent and neglectful in this particu
lar than the inhabitants of other paits of the United
States, if we are to judge from the numerous neat vaults,
monuments, tombs, head-stones, and other graveyard or
naments of the fine burial-ground of which I have spoken,
and with which I am astonished to learn from your corre
spondent that probably nine tenths of this city are only ac
quainted from " vague and uncertain rumor.” From the
great number of visiters almost daily to this cemetery, both
strangers and citizens, I should have supposed that there
was not one out of fifty that had not seen as well as heard
of it. It would indicate an ignorance and a want of curi
osity that I should be loath to impute to the people of
Washington. But if there be any who have never seen
it, and who can enjoy the melancholy gratification of med
itating among the monuments of the dead, or strolling
through the walks of this garden of graves, I would ad
vise him to remain no longer in ignorance, but to visit it
as soon as it may be convenient, and judge for himself
whether the citizens of Washington are amenable to the
charge which both “ G” and “ B” have thought proper to
bring against them. W.

EDITORS' CORRESPONDENCE.
New York, May 13, 1839.
An arrival from Valparaiso confirms the re
port of the defeat of Gen. Santa Cruz, “ Pro
tector” of Peru and Bolivia. The battle took
place in the north of Peru. The ship with
this news brings here nearly 200,000 dollars in
specie.
The case of Dixon, the soi-disant editor of a
hawk and buzzard sheet here called the Poly
anthus, has for some time attracted a good deal
of attention. He has just been tried for a libel
upon the Rev. Dr. Hawks, an Episcopal cler
gyman in this city of remarkable eloquence.
Dixon plead guilty to the libels, and the Court
to-day sentenced him to two months’ imprison
ment for each of three distinct libels, making
six months in all, to be spent in the peni
tentiary.
The Liverpool packet having been detained
till to-morrow, there have been some opera
tions in exchange, and the sales on London
have risen from 109 J to 109 J, and in some few
cases to 110, which is an advance not looked
for, and creating some sensation in the street.
The stock market, in consequence, has been
heavy. No spirit for speculation was manifest.
To-day ends the Whig City Government.
To-morrow is the installation of the Locofocos.
It is remarkable that Mr. Tallmadge, a bank di
rector, is to preside over the new Board of
Aidermen. Talk, you see, is one thing, and ac
tion is another. The Whigs are swept out to
morrow afternoon, with one dash of the broom
of reform.
M. Taglioni, the brother of the celebrated
Madame, has lately arrived in this city from Ber
lin. He is attached to the Royal Opera in Ber
lin, and is on leave for an excursion in America.

I knew men kept no promises—or none
At least with woman—and yet knowing this,
With credulous folly, still I trusted one,
W'hose word seem’d so like truth, that I forgot
The lesson I had lcarn’d full oft before;
Aad I believ’d because he said he’d come,
That he would come: and then night after night,
I watch’d the clouds and saw them pass away,
From the bright moon—and leave the clear blue
sky,
As spotless, and serene, and.beautiful,
As if no promises were broken e’er
Beneath it. Man forgets in busy heurs
What in his idle moments he has said,
Nor thinks how often Woman’s happiness
Hangs on his lightest words. It is not things
Of great importance which affect the heart
Most deeply—trifles often weave the net
Of misery or bliss in human life.
There’s many a deep and hidden grief that comes
From sources which admit of no complaint;
From things of which we cannot, dare not speak:
And yet they seem but trifles, till a chain,
Link after link, is fasten’d on each thought,
And wound around the heart—they do their work
In eecreey and silence—but their power
Is far more fatal than the open shafts
Of sorrow aud misfortune: for they prey
Upon the health and spirits, till the bloom
Of hope is changed into the hectic flush:
They break the charms of youth’s first brightest
dreams,
Aud thus wear out the pleasures of the world,
And sap, at length, the very springs of life;
But this is wotnau’s fate. It is not thus
With proud aspiring man—liis mind is fill’d
W ith high and lofty thoughts—and love and hope,
And all the warmest feelings of his heart,
Are sacrificed at cold ambition’s shrine.
He feels that the whole world was made for ms:;
And if some painful disappointment cross
His palk of life, lie does not change liis course:
Nor broken promises, nor hopes destroyed,
Are e’er allowed a place on memory’s page.
*Tis only Woman, iu her loneliness,
And in her silent, melancholy hours,
Who treasures in her heart the idle words
That had no meaning, and who lives on hope,
’Till it has stolen the color from her cheeks,
The brightness from her eyes,who trusts her peace
On the vast ocean of uncertainty—
And if ’tis wreck’d, she learns her lot to bear,
Or she may learn to die—but not forget.
It is for her to hoard her secret thoughts,
To brood o’er broken promises, and sigh
O’er disappointed hopes—’till she believes
1 here s less wretchedness in the wide world,
Thau in her single heart!
